body_text.text: Lung injury occurs frequently following HSCT and significantly contributes to morbidity and mortality in the immediate post transplant period and in the months and years that follow. It can be observed in 25–55% of recipients (Cooke and Yanik 2016).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Historically, approximately half of all pulmonary complications seen after HSCT were secondary to infection, but the judicious use of broad-spectrum antimicrobial agents has tipped the balance toward noninfectious causes.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Noninfectious lung injury following HSCT may be mediated by either immune or nonimmune mechanisms and could represent up to the 50% of noninfectious mortality after allo-HSCT.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: These complications have been classified by the American Thoracic Society according to the tissue primarily injured and its etiology (Panoskaltsis-Mortari et al. 2011) (Table 52.1).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Diagnostic yield could be as high as 80%.
body_text.section: Results Reported Using this Methodology (Seo et al. 2015CR19bibr; Lucena et al. 2014CR14bibr; Shannon et al. 2010CR20bibr) ::: Diagnostic Methodology of Pulmonary Complications

body_text.text: Sixty percent of diagnosis is achieved with noninvasive techniques.
body_text.section: Results Reported Using this Methodology (Seo et al. 2015CR19bibr; Lucena et al. 2014CR14bibr; Shannon et al. 2010CR20bibr) ::: Diagnostic Methodology of Pulmonary Complications

body_text.text: FOB/BAL permits an etiological diagnosis in up to 78% of cases.
body_text.section: Results Reported Using this Methodology (Seo et al. 2015CR19bibr; Lucena et al. 2014CR14bibr; Shannon et al. 2010CR20bibr) ::: Diagnostic Methodology of Pulmonary Complications

body_text.text: In suspected IPS, a BAL study may detect a pathogen in ~50% of cases.
body_text.section: Results Reported Using this Methodology (Seo et al. 2015CR19bibr; Lucena et al. 2014CR14bibr; Shannon et al. 2010CR20bibr) ::: Diagnostic Methodology of Pulmonary Complications

body_text.text: For pathogen detection, early FOB (<5 days) offer better yield than late FOB.
body_text.section: Results Reported Using this Methodology (Seo et al. 2015CR19bibr; Lucena et al. 2014CR14bibr; Shannon et al. 2010CR20bibr) ::: Diagnostic Methodology of Pulmonary Complications

body_text.text: The risk of complications with FOB is <5%.
body_text.section: Results Reported Using this Methodology (Seo et al. 2015CR19bibr; Lucena et al. 2014CR14bibr; Shannon et al. 2010CR20bibr) ::: Diagnostic Methodology of Pulmonary Complications

body_text.text: Despite not being included in most classifications of pulmonary complications after HSCT, pulmonary edema (PE) as a consequence of a fluid overload (FO) is extremely frequent (Rondón et al. 2017).
body_text.section: Pulmonary Edema Due to Fluid Overload

body_text.text: Widespread alveolar injury in absence of active lower respiratory tract infection, cardiac or renal dysfunction, and iatrogenic fluid overload (Clark et al. 1993; Panoskaltsis-Mortari et al. 2011)
body_text.section: Definition ::: Idiopathic Pneumonia Syndrome

body_text.text: Characterized by development around day +20 after HSCT of fever and nonproductive cough, dyspnea, tachypnea, hypoxemia, rales, and diffuse alveolar or interstitial infiltrates on x-rays or CT scans.
body_text.section: Clinical Manifestations ::: Idiopathic Pneumonia Syndrome

body_text.text: All of the following must be present for accepting the IPS diagnosis:
body_text.section: Diagnosis ::: Idiopathic Pneumonia Syndrome
Pathogenesis, Incidence, Presentation, and Risk Factors ::: Idiopathic Pneumonia Syndrome
Treatment and Prognosis ::: Idiopathic Pneumonia Syndrome
Clinical Aspects of DAH ::: Diffuse Alveolar Hemorrhage (DAH)
Treatment and Prognosis of DAH ::: Diffuse Alveolar Hemorrhage (DAH)

body_text.text: Pathogenesis, timing, incidence, clinical manifestations, diagnosis, and radiology of BOS are shown in Table 52.2.
body_text.section: Bronchiolitis Obliterans Syndrome (BOS) ::: Late-Onset Noninfectious Pulmonary Complications (LONIPC)

body_text.text: Treatment and prognosis of BOS are included in Table 52.3.
body_text.section: Bronchiolitis Obliterans Syndrome (BOS) ::: Late-Onset Noninfectious Pulmonary Complications (LONIPC)

body_text.text: Lung injury occurs frequently following HSCT and significantly contributes to morbidity and mortality in the immediate post transplant period and in the months and years that follow. It can be observed in 25–55% of recipients.Noninfectious lung injury following HSCT may be mediated by either immune or nonimmune mechanisms and could represent up to the 50% of noninfectious mortality after allo-HSCT.Most relevant noninfectious early pulmonary complications are pulmonary edema by fluid overflow, idiopathic pneumonia syndrome, and diffuse alveolar hemorrhage, a vascular endothelial syndrome.The most relevant late-onset noninfectious pulmonary complications are bronchiolitis obliterans and cryptogenetic organizing pneumonia.All of them have specific diagnostic criteria, management, treatment, and prognosis.
body_text.section: Key Points ::: Cryptogenetic Organizing Pneumonia (COP) ::: Late-Onset Noninfectious Pulmonary Complications (LONIPC)

TABREF0.text:
Table 52.1: Noninfectious pulmonary complications after HSCTa


aImportantly, this classification does not include the most frequent lung complication after HSCT, i.e., pulmonary edema secondary to fluid overload 
bAll these complications are categorized as IPS 
cFormerly called bronchiolitis obliterans organizing pneumonia (BOOP)

TABREF1.text:
Table 52.2: Main clinical characteristics of BOS

DLCO transfer capacity of CO, FEV1 maximum expiratory volume in the first second, FVC forced vital capacity, VATS video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery 
aSome experts consider that a 10% decrease in the FEV1 basal after HSCT should make you suspect in BOS diagnosis 
bIf the lung is the only organ with cGVHD, a biopsy is needed to confirm the diagnosis (NIH criteria) 
cRarely transbronchial biopsy is used (low sensitivity and low predictive value) to establish a diagnosis that is eminently clinical. If histology is available, the term bronchiolitis obliterans can be used; if not available, the process is referred to as BOS

TABREF2.text:
Table 52.3: Treatment and prognosis of BOS

aFluticasone theoretically decreases the inflammatory pulmonary component; azithromycin reduces IL-8 levels and neutrophilia; and montelukast is an antagonist of the leukotriene receptors (bronchodilator) 
bHowever, the ALLOZITHRO randomized trial has shown that early administration of azithromycin resulted in worse airflow decline-free survival than did placebo; the value of these findings is limited by early termination of the trial (Bergeron et al. 2017)

TABREF3.text:
Table 52.4: Differential diagnosis between BOS and COP

CRP C-reactive protein 
aIf patients are adequately controlled, it is common to detect restrictive alterations before the day +100 although clinical manifestations may appear later 
b
Mycoplasma, Coxiella, Nocardia, and various viruses 
cAmiodarone, bleomycin, busulfan, and cephalosporins
